unnormalised: AIIMS Delhi reported a spike in dengue cases this week, with 150+ patients admitted as of 20/07/2024. Dr. Sharma, the head of the infectious diseases dept., urged citizens to take preventive measures. "Folks, mosquitos are having a field day! Clear out stagnant water, use mosquito repellent, and don't take fever lightly," she advised. The hospital is also running a 24/7 helpline; call 1800-11-1234 for info.
normalised: A-I-I-M-S Delhi reported a spike in dengue cases this week, with one hundred and fifty plus patients admitted as of twentieth july two thousand and twenty four. Doctor Sharma, the head of the infectious diseases department, urged citizens to take preventive measures. "Folks, mosquitos are having a field day! Clear out stagnant water, use mosquito repellent, and don't take fever lightly," she advised. The hospital is also running a twenty four seven helpline; call one eight hundred eleven one thousand two hundred and thirty four for info.

unnormalised: Meanwhile, the BMC in Mumbai has launched a door-to-door campaign in Dharavi, distributing mosquito nets and educating residents about symptoms. The campaign aims to cover 50,000+ households by 31/07/2024. According to a BMC official, Mr. Desai, early detection is key to managing the outbreak. "If you have a fever, headache, or rash, get tested ASAP. Don't wait," he emphasized.
normalised: Meanwhile, the B-M-C in Mumbai has launched a door-to-door campaign in Dharavi, distributing mosquito nets and educating residents about symptoms. The campaign aims to cover fifty thousand plus households by thirty first july two thousand and twenty four. According to a B-M-C official, Mister Desai, early detection is key to managing the outbreak. "If you have a fever, headache, or rash, get tested A-S-A-P. Don't wait," he emphasized.

unnormalised: The Kerala government has announced a state-wide alert, especially in coastal areas where waterlogging is common. Health Minister Veena George has instructed all district medical officers to ensure adequate stocks of medicines and testing kits. "We are working on a war footing to prevent the spread of dengue and other vector-borne diseases," she stated. The government has also allocated Rs. 5 crore for awareness campaigns.
normalised: The Kerala government has announced a state-wide alert, especially in coastal areas where waterlogging is common. Health Minister Veena George has instructed all district medical officers to ensure adequate stocks of medicines and testing kits. "We are working on a war footing to prevent the spread of dengue and other vector-borne diseases," she stated. The government has also allocated rupees five crore for awareness campaigns.

unnormalised: In Guwahati, the situation is equally concerning, with the GMC reporting a 30% increase in cases compared to last month. Several schools have temporarily suspended outdoor activities. Dr. Baruah, a leading physician, recommends wearing long sleeves and using mosquito repellent during peak mosquito hours (5 PM - 7 PM). "Prevention is better than cure, folks. Stay safe and take care," he added.
normalised: In Guwahati, the situation is equally concerning, with the G-M-C reporting a thirty percent increase in cases compared to last month. Several schools have temporarily suspended outdoor activities. Doctor Baruah, a leading physician, recommends wearing long sleeves and using mosquito repellent during peak mosquito hours (five P-M - seven P-M). "Prevention is better than cure, folks. Stay safe and take care," he added.

unnormalised: Citizens are advised to consult a doctor immediately if they experience any symptoms of dengue. Self-medication is strongly discouraged. Remember, staying vigilant and taking preventive measures can go a long way in protecting ourselves and our communities. Let's all do our bit to combat this public health challenge.
normalised: Citizens are advised to consult a doctor immediately if they experience any symptoms of dengue. Self-medication is strongly discouraged. Remember, staying vigilant and taking preventive measures can go a long way in protecting ourselves and our communities. Let's all do our bit to combat this public health challenge.
